Mar 14, 2013 Maureen rated it did not like it
Not my kind of book. The author was all over the place. I typically read books quickly and this one took me just about a month because everytime I picked it up, I would fall asleep. I probably missed some pieces b/c I had to skim over some of the rants from the main character, Paul. It just never caught my attention and I didn't think the character development was good. I could not relate to any of the characters. I was halfway through the book when a little bit of action happened, but even Not my kind of book. The author was all over the place. I typically read books quickly and this one took me just about a month because everytime I picked it up, I would fall asleep. I probably missed some pieces b/c I had to skim over some of the rants from the main character, Paul. It just never caught my attention and I didn't think the character development was good. I could not relate to any of the characters. I was halfway through the book when a little bit of action happened, but even still it wasn't all that great.

Told from the perspective of Paul, The Dinner is about a family with a secret they are meeting to discuss at a fancy restaurant. Completely unrealistic! I never felt like I knew where Paul was going in the story. The minute attention to detail was agonizing as each meal for each course of the dinner was reviewed. Paul has some kind of mental illness and as he introduces different pieces about others in the family he self invokes, HIPPA, which is weird in a book leaving readers to wonder what happened with many of the characters. I didn't like him at all as a character. By the end of the book, I was confused with lots of questions...primarily, what was the point of the story? Additionally, it was extremely drawn out. Best part of the book was being done with it. i'm interested to discuss at our next book club meeting to see what others thought.

Many people compared this to Gone Girl and I completely disagree. Gone Girl was action packed from start to end and this book certainly was not. ...more

Apr 03, 2013 Nada rated it did not like it
Review first published on my blog: http://memoriesfrombooks.blogspot.com...

The Dinner takes place over the course of one evening - one dinner shared among two couples. Serge and Babette. Paul and Claire. Over the course of the dinner, much is revealed about the dynamics of the two couples and about the relationship of brothers Serge and Paul. Both couples have children, and the dinner revolves around an event involving their fifteen year old sons.

The book is written as a first person narrative Review first published on my blog: http://memoriesfrombooks.blogspot.com...

The Dinner takes place over the course of one evening - one dinner shared among two couples. Serge and Babette. Paul and Claire. Over the course of the dinner, much is revealed about the dynamics of the two couples and about the relationship of brothers Serge and Paul. Both couples have children, and the dinner revolves around an event involving their fifteen year old sons.

The book is written as a first person narrative with Paul as the narrator. The setting is Amsterdam. The central issue is that the two couples' sons have committed a senseless act that has serious legal ramifications. The two couples differ in their approach to this issue. For the bulk of the book, they dance around the issue and parry back and forth over the dinner.

The conversation brings out serious issues in the relationships between the two brothers. One suffers from mental illness that causes violent bursts of temper. The other is submerged in political machinations and election maneuverings. The two wives bring their own perspectives and agendas.

I found the book disturbing and difficult to read. The characters are not likable. The parental approach to the trouble the boys have caused is disturbing. The first person narrative makes the book more difficult; perhaps, a different perspective or different narrators might have added more depth to the story. Overall, this is one dinner I wish I had skipped. ...more

Jul 29, 2014 Diana rated it did not like it
Shelves: bookclub
This review has been hidden because it contains spoilers. To view it, click here. No.
Just... no.

Not only was this novel unspeakably slow and ridiculously drawn-out (was that supposed to be building tension? Putting its hooks into me? Lawd, I hope not) but then it twisted - and not in a good way - and even that wasn't enough to make me want to keep reading.

And I love reading.

There are plenty of great novels about sociopaths -Morgan, Lecter, de Large... creepy, horrifying, yet interesting reads that at least make you want to keep reading (even if you want to cover your eyes at No.
Just... no.

Not only was this novel unspeakably slow and ridiculously drawn-out (was that supposed to be building tension? Putting its hooks into me? Lawd, I hope not) but then it twisted - and not in a good way - and even that wasn't enough to make me want to keep reading.

And I love reading.

There are plenty of great novels about sociopaths -Morgan, Lecter, de Large... creepy, horrifying, yet interesting reads that at least make you want to keep reading (even if you want to cover your eyes at the same time).

And when a sociopath is written well, that tiny piece of you, deep down, is actually *rooting* for them- dying (heh) to know what they'll think of next.

This book? Nope. Not even a little. Maybe it was lost in the translation from the original Dutch?

The casual approach to two teens who killed a homeless person was terrible enough... but at the end? That poor adopted son, Beau... you know Claire instructed the boys (or at least Michael) to "solve the problem" and when Paul sees him come in covered in dirt, you know that innocent African kid is dead.

The bit about Claire and the genetic test was very interesting, too - did she know her son was going to be a nut job because of Paul? and just not care? Did she think Paul would have wanted her to get an abortion so she lied about both parents consenting to the test? I'm not sure if this was a weird afterthought, but it didn't make me feel very different about any of the characters or the book itself.

One star. Blah. ...more

Most mental illness can't be determined by genetic testing, much less (view spoiler)[I quickly hated all the characters, but I hadn't given up on the book until this mental illness. There's no such mental illness, which repeatedly puts the MC into bloody rages. These weren't blind rages, even; he simply found violence a logical answer. If it were presented as a character flaw I might go along? but not a disease, and not (this upset me terribly) a disease that can be detected in amniotic fluid. Most mental illness can't be determined by genetic testing, much less an amniotic fluid test.

Eh, I shouldn't put the flaws of the book down to that. It was supposed to be a good psychological thriller. But not one character acted normally, humanly, rationally-- not even with animal instincts; like some dinner of aliens. I constantly wondered on what planet this would be normal.

The narrator was obnoxious. How many times did he refuse to name a place or go into detail. Evil and psychopathic characters I don't mind, but unbelievable and obnoxious ones I do. Speaking of unbelievable, Serge is OK eating with the brother who bloodied him? I suppose Claire's violence at the end is more understandable, then. Serge is not intelligent & will probably forget it.

The ending didn't solve anything, was less believable than the rest of the book (which is saying a lot). (hide spoiler)]

Secondly, I am a parent myself and I understand that a lot of people see this book as a story about how far you go to protect your children. I think that is partially Horrible book!! My sister recommended this to me. She said her book club really liked it, so I figured it was worth a try. First of all. the writing was so boring and slow moving that I ended up just skimming a lot of it. Way too many details that were not needed and had nothing to do with the story (like the food descriptions).

Secondly, I am a parent myself and I understand that a lot of people see this book as a story about how far you go to protect your children. I think that is partially true, but that is not what bothered me. What was so awful was that the parents of Michel (Paul & Claire) did not even seem to.think he did anything wrong! They kept trying to justify his actions and blame the victim. They just seemed like despicable human beings. Supposedly Paul had some sort of mental disorder that caused him to be a complete ass who regularly beat people up if they made him angry. The supposition was that his son inherited this from him. That does not explain his wife's behavior. Also, he chose to go off his medication that controlled his condition.

I only finished to book because I read other reviews of how bad the ending was and I was curious. I will say I agree with the reviews about the horrible ending. It was not surprising given how bad the rest of the book was. This is the most scathing review I have ever written and I am honestly kind of mad at my sister for recommending this book. ...more

Oct 26, 2016 Polly rated it did not like it
Ugh. This was a book club pick. Was wary from the get-go with the "Gone Girl" comparison, but hey, we have good discussions and it's my commitment to read our monthly book so i dove right in. The cute construction of mapping each progressively deteriorating stage of discussion to courses as a restaurant was cloying, but I soldiered on. As the meal (and predictable plot line) moved forward and the characters became more hateful, I was tempted to toss the book aside. But it was short, so...read on Ugh. This was a book club pick. Was wary from the get-go with the "Gone Girl" comparison, but hey, we have good discussions and it's my commitment to read our monthly book so i dove right in. The cute construction of mapping each progressively deteriorating stage of discussion to courses as a restaurant was cloying, but I soldiered on. As the meal (and predictable plot line) moved forward and the characters became more hateful, I was tempted to toss the book aside. But it was short, so...read on i did.

Brief pros: gave me an insight into the Dutch psyche and convoluted feelings about their form of government (or at least their weak elected officials and lowly world status). The bits about the waiter pointing to and elucidating the provenance of each bit of (tiny) food on the (large) plates was funny at first, but got old.

Cons: Hateful characters to whom it's impossible to relate. I suspect the author was trying to challenge us on the nature of parenting and what people will do to protect their offspring, but honestly i didn't care whether the father, mother, and son all roasted in hell, by the end. The addition of an adopted African son seemed contrived and unnecessary; i don't think the plot would've changed one whit were he also Dutch. So much more to hate, but it's back to work for me.
Avoid this book unless you're utterly bored or desperate for reading material. in the latter case, you'd be better off cruising almost any blog post online.
...more

Feb 17, 2014 Michelle Hart rated it did not like it
Shelves: read-2014
While the book does make you wonder how far you would go to protect family, there FAR too many questions left dangling. The beginning of the book is intriguing. Two brothers and their wives meet for dinner. Everyone knows something and isn't sure who else knows and/or how much they know. By the end of the book, I didn't even care anymore. None of the characters are likable. I didn't care who knew what when and I didn't care how they all ended up. I just wanted the book finished.

I personally While the book does make you wonder how far you would go to protect family, there FAR too many questions left dangling. The beginning of the book is intriguing. Two brothers and their wives meet for dinner. Everyone knows something and isn't sure who else knows and/or how much they know. By the end of the book, I didn't even care anymore. None of the characters are likable. I didn't care who knew what when and I didn't care how they all ended up. I just wanted the book finished.

I personally found the 'I'm not going to tell you the specifics of _______' tactic that was repeated numerous times throughout the book to be incredibly annoying. I can only presume the author thought it cute or clever. It wasn't. Tell me, or don't, but don't say 'there was an illness, but I'm not going to tell you the name of it'. Certainly don't use the same I'm-so-coy tactic over and over about various subjects. That makes me say 'fine, don't tell me, I don't care anyway'.

I thought the video was going to be an entirely different secret than it turned out to be. The reveal of the video's subject was a surprise to me. What the video turned out to be was an interesting plot twist. Unfortunately, that was the only interesting twist.

The book could have been so good. The premise was good. The execution and conclusion? Not so much. ...more

This book is strange to say the very least. It would be interesting to know what native readers think of it since it was written by a Dutch gentleman. I do not pretend to be familiar with the culture/differences in use of language. Thus, some of my dislike may stem from this lack of familiarity. No matter what the source, literature should be universal in it's scope. I found the conversations in the book to be disappointingly flat. I did not feel for the characters nor completely *mild spoilers*

This book is strange to say the very least. It would be interesting to know what native readers think of it since it was written by a Dutch gentleman. I do not pretend to be familiar with the culture/differences in use of language. Thus, some of my dislike may stem from this lack of familiarity. No matter what the source, literature should be universal in it's scope. I found the conversations in the book to be disappointingly flat. I did not feel for the characters nor completely understand their points of view. The setting of the story is extremely odd. This family needs to meet to discuss family secrets, so where do they go? -Out to dinner. -Huh? Also, highly implausible that the father's tantrums? haven't caused the family more hardships. There are twists, but they are largely unimaginative. Of note, the "restaurant scene" is focused upon highly, though uninterestingly, in the first half of the book and then hurried through after "the main course". I don't agree with other reviews that I have read that describe this as a look into the lengths people will go to protect their families. I more saw it as a peek into the upbringing of a psychopath...It's no wonder his kid did what he did.

I did actually make it through the book, but, as another reviewer put it,...I'd already spent the money. ...more

Jan 18, 2015 Peter rated it did not like it
The Dinner by Herman Koch is a novel that will either totally engage the reader or completely turn the reader off. Clearly, I stand in the second camp.

The premise and theme of the book has much to offer but my problem with the book lies in its delivery. To me, the characters were flat, wooden and unconvincing. This was, perhaps, a conscious decision by Koch to portray them as such, but for me the characters interfered with the story, rather than enhanced it. If Koch was attempting a "noir" feel The Dinner by Herman Koch is a novel that will either totally engage the reader or completely turn the reader off. Clearly, I stand in the second camp.

The premise and theme of the book has much to offer but my problem with the book lies in its delivery. To me, the characters were flat, wooden and unconvincing. This was, perhaps, a conscious decision by Koch to portray them as such, but for me the characters interfered with the story, rather than enhanced it. If Koch was attempting a "noir" feel to the book, that is fine, but the reader still must engage with the characters either to like them or dislike them. Can there be anything worse in a novel that not to care about any of its characters?

The issue the parents in this novel must confront and deal with, while extreme, is still certainly valid, and the question of to what extent parents will go to forgive, or worse, ignore, the faults and transgressions of their children is an important one. Nevertheless, in this novel the gradual unveiling of the crime, the cover up and the related background of the story are not enough to give much satisfaction to the reading experience.

Overall, the novel seemed to lurch towards its conclusion, which had some promise as to a twist ending, but it left me unsatisfied. ...more

Jul 20, 2016 Jay Tate rated it did not like it
Was this worse than Gone Girl? That's a hard one. Gone Girl at least had a plot twist. The Dinner (aka the life and times of some really horrible people) dances around the plot for 250 pages, then rushes to a predictable finish. I'm torn between 1 and 2 stars - but I can't come up with a good reason for 2.

Fiction that explores how far a person will go to protect himself and his family should be easy to carry off. I'm a parent - I get it. And if it were just parents deciding to go all No Thugs in Was this worse than Gone Girl? That's a hard one. Gone Girl at least had a plot twist. The Dinner (aka the life and times of some really horrible people) dances around the plot for 250 pages, then rushes to a predictable finish. I'm torn between 1 and 2 stars - but I can't come up with a good reason for 2.

Fiction that explores how far a person will go to protect himself and his family should be easy to carry off. I'm a parent - I get it. And if it were just parents deciding to go all No Thugs in Our House then it would be understandable. The problem with this mess is that it's so contrived it comes off poorly. It felt a bit like this:

"I would tell you more information, but I don't want to. Instead, I will refer to things eight times and then move on. If you'd like, you can skip 2-3 pages and pick up right where you are - you won't miss much if you do. Did I tell you I really like my wife? She's nice. And I used to teach. And the waiter is bugging me. And I would nail my sis-in-law in a heartbeat, but I really like my wife. My brother wouldn't mind - after all, he'd definitely nail my wife if the waiter weren't taking so long. I wonder if my sis-in-law wants to nail my wife, too. There's a visual! I'm all in. But, back to our story. Where was I?" ...more

Mar 30, 2014 Nicole rated it did not like it
The Dinner by Herman Koch turned out to be a book that I would never ever read again or recommend to anyone to waste their time reading. To summarize, two couples are meeting for dinner to discuss what to do about the terrible thing that their teenagers did and somehow was caught on video. Opposite ends of the parental spectrum, one wants them to confess while the other will stop at nothing to keep it secret. All of this plays out over the course of the worst dinner ever.

I get that the author The Dinner by Herman Koch turned out to be a book that I would never ever read again or recommend to anyone to waste their time reading. To summarize, two couples are meeting for dinner to discuss what to do about the terrible thing that their teenagers did and somehow was caught on video. Opposite ends of the parental spectrum, one wants them to confess while the other will stop at nothing to keep it secret. All of this plays out over the course of the worst dinner ever.

I get that the author was trying to show the complexity of family interactions and how we really don't know what we would do until faced with a no win situation. However, the characters behave in such odd ways, were terribly unlikable and although I can understand the writers purpose, I just can't get around the convenience of the plot. With the single point of view the narrator, we are only able to experience all these moving parts from his perspective only. Combined with odd flashbacks and the ending seems as if the writer was trying to prove a point but forgot to let the reader know.

Overall, I'd give it a D. ...more

Jul 06, 2013 Jennifer rated it did not like it
Shelves: mysterythriller, icky-people-making-icky-choices
Quite a nasty piece of work; probably the most misanthropic thing I've ever read. The story becomes both increasingly hateful and far-fetched as it goes on. Ugh.

Some reviews have alluded to the moral or ethical questions that the book raises, but as far as I can see there is no moral interrogation going on. The book functions mainly for shock value -- what one reviewer described as a 300 page troll.

*spoilers*

This is all dependent on the reader suspending disbelief enough to buy highly unlikely Quite a nasty piece of work; probably the most misanthropic thing I've ever read. The story becomes both increasingly hateful and far-fetched as it goes on. Ugh.

Some reviews have alluded to the moral or ethical questions that the book raises, but as far as I can see there is no moral interrogation going on. The book functions mainly for shock value -- what one reviewer described as a 300 page troll.

*spoilers*

This is all dependent on the reader suspending disbelief enough to buy highly unlikely and contrived behavior that doesn't resemble anything actual people do (i.e. going to a public restaurant to discuss a crime cover up to name just one.) The mysterious genetic illness and prenatal detection of psychopathy is utter b.s. Plus the characters' amorality and lack of any realistic legal response to their actions renders the "how far would you go to protect your children?" question moot. The question the book really poses is more along the lines of "how far would you go for your children IF you were total psychopaths AND ALSO there were no social repercussions for your violent actions whatsoever." Wow-deep. ...more

May 15, 2013 Simon Lipson rated it did not like it
Well I don't know. I'm trying to figure out why this book has been so widely lauded and sold so many copies. It's loathsome. I'm kicking myself for bothering to finish it, but I thought Koch would eventually subvert the obnoxious tone in order to somehow redeem his vile, amoral protagonists.

Ok, this is what it's about: Two brothers and their wives get together over dinner at a swanky, overpriced restaurant, to discuss what to do about their teenage children who have done something awful. The gag Well I don't know. I'm trying to figure out why this book has been so widely lauded and sold so many copies. It's loathsome. I'm kicking myself for bothering to finish it, but I thought Koch would eventually subvert the obnoxious tone in order to somehow redeem his vile, amoral protagonists.

Ok, this is what it's about: Two brothers and their wives get together over dinner at a swanky, overpriced restaurant, to discuss what to do about their teenage children who have done something awful. The gag - well, I assume it's meant to be a gag - is that the parents are even more misanthropic and dysfunctional than their offspring. The principal protagonist is a whining, bitter, violent, hateful thug and his wife is not much better. His brother - wannabe next PM of Holland - is a vacuous narcissist and only his wife demonstrates even a hint of humanity.

I assume this is intended to be a black comedy highlighting the amorality of the middle classes, particularly when it comes to protecting their children. It's black, but it ain't funny. One tone - relentlessly nasty - with nothing that connects any character to anyone you've ever known.

Yuck. ...more

I understand all the talking points on this book, I get it. Mental stability (errr I mean instability?). The whole how far does one go to protect their loved ones. Are they crazy because they are protecting their children? Or would they be crazy not to? I'm not sure that's what makes them (Paul and Claire) crazy.

Anyways, I think the unreliable narration from Paul was just too much for me. Satire or not, Paul's whiny, egotistical, and Long time reader of reviews, first time reviewing.

I understand all the talking points on this book, I get it. Mental stability (errr I mean instability?). The whole how far does one go to protect their loved ones. Are they crazy because they are protecting their children? Or would they be crazy not to? I'm not sure that's what makes them (Paul and Claire) crazy.

Anyways, I think the unreliable narration from Paul was just too much for me. Satire or not, Paul's whiny, egotistical, and semi-narcissistic nature bothered me. The plot reminded me of something out of an M. Night Shyamalan film. Not signs, or that one with Sam Jackson either. Probably The Village. Yeah, that one. Pretty fitting, seeing that many people enjoyed that movie and many people despised it. The characters all bothered me, as well as the overall attitude of the novel. I know the author probably made them pretentious, unlikable ass hats on purpose, so hats off to him for doing a great job in generating my hatred. I just couldn't find anything to like in this book.

The ending bothered me. Come on, man!

I think I was just bothered overall. ...more

Aug 16, 2014 Ciarán Lumsden rated it did not like it
I like the premise of this book, a dinner conversation that turns sour , unfolding pieces of the dark past in layers, getting more disturbing the further we go along. I thought it might be a bit like the Danish film 'Festen'. We have an aspiring Dutch prime minister and his wife , his brother an 'on leave' history teacher and his wife, and a crime that their teenage children have committed, which reveals as much about the parents as human beings as it does their children.

I dilly dallied for I like the premise of this book, a dinner conversation that turns sour , unfolding pieces of the dark past in layers, getting more disturbing the further we go along. I thought it might be a bit like the Danish film 'Festen'. We have an aspiring Dutch prime minister and his wife , his brother an 'on leave' history teacher and his wife, and a crime that their teenage children have committed, which reveals as much about the parents as human beings as it does their children.

I dilly dallied for months on this one because of some of the negative reviews, but heard the author on the radio recently. He sounded intelligent and engaging, so I reconsidered reading this. Big mistake.

It was extremely dull. Not one paragraph held my attention or engaged me in any way. Nothing happens , all the characters are bores and amoral, the plot is plodding, the writing workmanlike at best. It would be definitely the worst book I have read in the last 12 months if it were not for the yawn extravaganza that was Gone Girl. At least this was short and didn't irritate the hell out of me. Will not be rereading and would not recommend to anyone. Don't do it. ...more

I'm feeling sorry I still have to give this a 1-star. Impossible to give a lower rate, it seems.

OMG - it takes almost over half the book (120 pages) to get to (maybe?) something interesting. What bullshit this is!
Even if the other half may be intriguing and even thriller-like, this is too much of an introduction.

Remember "Chronicle of a death foretold" by Marquez where we know from the first sentence that Santiago will die, and where Marquez can still keep us on the edge for the rest of the story. Now THAT is literature!
Who needs 120 pages of rubbish to start of a story???

And I could get into detail and comment on stupid paragraphs and even pages long of non-interesting descriptions that have nothing to do with the story or give any more insight information in the characters involved - who are not interesting anyway.

Even the style is disgusting. Nothing interesting happens - OK - but even the non-events are written in a language not worth reading.

Maybe the second half of the book is OK - I will never know. Life is too short to find out and there are far more better books to discover.

This is another novel where I understand why people enjoy it and it is acclaimed, but I just didn't enjoy it all. I didn't even finish the story I was so annoyed by the characters. I truly hated them so much that I didn't care what happened to them. My sister, who is evil and didn't warn me off this novel actually summarized the last third of the book for me. And you know what? It was completely predictable. I could tell you the basic gist about a third in... and I wish I had stopped there. This is another novel where I understand why people enjoy it and it is acclaimed, but I just didn't enjoy it all. I didn't even finish the story I was so annoyed by the characters. I truly hated them so much that I didn't care what happened to them. My sister, who is evil and didn't warn me off this novel actually summarized the last third of the book for me. And you know what? It was completely predictable. I could tell you the basic gist about a third in... and I wish I had stopped there. There are no particulars aside from the characterizations that I was unhappy with, but when I can't stand the characters enough to care if they all are killed in some zombie apocalypse during dinner (which did not happen, but I would have liked to see and totally would have kept my attention)then the story doesn't work for me no matter how well it is written or what interesting twist you throw in.

It may be your cup of tea and I think it's at least a quick perusal as you look for a new novel to read, but do me just one favor.

If you end up loving it, keep it to yourself.

I enjoy believing my opinions are the only accurate ones. ...more

Apr 18, 2016 Kirsten rated it did not like it
I was really looking forward to reading this due to the hype, but ultimately not a fan. The only character I didn't outright HATE (they were all horrible human beings) was Serge.... the character that the narrator most wanted the reader to despise. I'm no pie-eyed optimist, but the fact that NONE of the adults or teenagers in this horrible contrived scenario chose to do anything even approaching the right thing made me feel like praying for humanity every time I put the bookmark in at night. To I was really looking forward to reading this due to the hype, but ultimately not a fan. The only character I didn't outright HATE (they were all horrible human beings) was Serge.... the character that the narrator most wanted the reader to despise. I'm no pie-eyed optimist, but the fact that NONE of the adults or teenagers in this horrible contrived scenario chose to do anything even approaching the right thing made me feel like praying for humanity every time I put the bookmark in at night. To make matters worse, I had initially picked up the book since it was regularly compared to , and recommended for lovers of , Gillian Flynn's Gone Girl. I saw none of the GG suspense reflected in The Dinner; there is no doubt who committed the crime, and almost no doubt that the perpetrators would skate away from their responsibilities in the end. It was all about what skeevy plan these degenerates would put in motion to get there. All in all... this book was like a Big Mac. I finished it quickly, yep..... but I didn't enjoy it and just want to purge it almost immediately. ...more

Feb 22, 2015 Barbara Ab rated it did not like it
Personally, for me, reading this book was a complete waste of time (read during a sleepless night). The general topic was already known and of not interest to me. The developing of the plot is terribly boring with a dysfunctional father figure being depicted by his personal memories during an annoying description of the dinner (restaurant and each course). It is not about actually teenagers with problems, but parents with problems and a society who do not have the courage to protect people in Personally, for me, reading this book was a complete waste of time (read during a sleepless night). The general topic was already known and of not interest to me. The developing of the plot is terribly boring with a dysfunctional father figure being depicted by his personal memories during an annoying description of the dinner (restaurant and each course). It is not about actually teenagers with problems, but parents with problems and a society who do not have the courage to protect people in the name of “fair correctness” (a person with a disorder who can become dangerous should be restricted no matter what… ). The craziness of the story is that the one who should be in an asylum is the leading character who succeeds at the end of the story with his hypocrite wife. The figure of a politician who wanted to report his son for committing a crime and giving up his political career on the contrary seems to be the only to blame. I know a lot of people who justify everything as long as it comes to their own benefit, so I was only bored by this reading about people and society hypocrisy. ...more

Apr 30, 2016 Brian Grover rated it did not like it
I have been reading books for as many of my 40 years on this Earth as I can remember, and it's safe to say I've never hated a book more than I hated this. It's about a family of psychopaths who plan the murder of their adopted nephew, while the parents conspire w/ the narrator's brother and his wife as to how to cover up some other murders their kids have committed over dinner one night. When the brother, who's the only character in this book who's not a lunatic, suggests that they turn the kids I have been reading books for as many of my 40 years on this Earth as I can remember, and it's safe to say I've never hated a book more than I hated this. It's about a family of psychopaths who plan the murder of their adopted nephew, while the parents conspire w/ the narrator's brother and his wife as to how to cover up some other murders their kids have committed over dinner one night. When the brother, who's the only character in this book who's not a lunatic, suggests that they turn the kids in, the others stab him in the face, which for some reason makes him change his mind.

This book is surpassed in its vileness only by its laughable implausibility, and I have no idea why Koch is apparently a popular author in Europe. I think he's a hack writer, regardless of the subject matter. I was so offended by the back jacket blurb from the WSJ review that called it "A European Gone Girl" that I googled the review, and - this is funny - it's a lukewarm review that doesn't make any reference to Gone Girl at all. Guys! What? ...more

Apr 29, 2013 Lulu rated it did not like it
Shelves: book-club
(Spoiler alert). I hated this book. There is nothing redeeming about it, the characters are either sociopathic, immoral, or amoral and the plot revolves around a senseless, heinous act committed by a few teenagers which is never resolved in even the smallest way. The setting in a posh restaurant with all the rituals of high-brow dining was an interesting device meant to build sympathy for the narrator and color our perceptions of the other characters. However we learn soon enough that the (Spoiler alert). I hated this book. There is nothing redeeming about it, the characters are either sociopathic, immoral, or amoral and the plot revolves around a senseless, heinous act committed by a few teenagers which is never resolved in even the smallest way. The setting in a posh restaurant with all the rituals of high-brow dining was an interesting device meant to build sympathy for the narrator and color our perceptions of the other characters. However we learn soon enough that the narrator is not reliable. At the end the reader is left with nothing; I had the same empty, despairing feeling I get when reading about flash mobs or cruelty to animals in the newspaper. Our book group did spend more time on this one than most other books, exploring how we as parents would deal with a psychopathic offspring. Thankfully most of us will never be in quite this position; however it's not hard to imagine that we wouldn't behave like the parent characters in the book, condoning or even helping to cover up a brutal murder. ...more

Sick, twisted, ridiculously ambiguous. . . there is not a whole lot to like about this book. I cannot tell whether the author holds the viewpoint of his morally reprehensible characters or is mocking it. This book is about protecting children from vile mistakes they made, and avoiding consequences of extremely immoral actions. There is no lesson in this book, and I'm somewhat disgusted by it's contents. This book is about protecting children from vile mistakes they made, and avoiding consequences of extremely immoral actions. SPOILER ALERT: Furthermore, the narrator and his son, and perhaps his wife as well, are psychologically ill, perhaps a combination of narcissism and bipolar, but the disorder is not revealed by the author. As someone who is studying to be a counselor, I would normally have empathy for someone like this, but the author does a great job of making sure I hate the characters. Perhaps that was his goal. Feb 18, 2014 Grace rated it did not like it
i guess i'm just utterly happy that it's finally over. it feels like i've been reading this book since the beginning of time.

the concept of intertwining the story with the family get-together dinner is interesting. but that's about as far as the appeal can go. sadly the dinner items totally eclipsed the storyline.

the author's repetitive use of "i don't wanna name this and that" then spending quite some printer ink on why the hell he doesn't wanna name those damn places, is, well, extremely i guess i'm just utterly happy that it's finally over. it feels like i've been reading this book since the beginning of time.

the concept of intertwining the story with the family get-together dinner is interesting. but that's about as far as the appeal can go. sadly the dinner items totally eclipsed the storyline.

the author's repetitive use of "i don't wanna name this and that" then spending quite some printer ink on why the hell he doesn't wanna name those damn places, is, well, extremely unnecessary. as a reader, i'd be happy if he just jolly told me the damn names and moved on with the story.

it seems, almost all characters in the book, with the exception of Serge (ironically), are suffering from various mental problems. the intention to showcase how families stick together during trying times or selfless parental protection over their children failed to deliver. the Lohmans just look to me a morbid family consisting of an emotionally challenged father, a psychopathic mother and a murderer son. just not a pretty family portrait.
